explanations.A: When we divide a fraction, we don't need to divide the numerator and the denominator. 2/4 is equivalent to 4/8, rather than half of it.
explanations.B: When we divide a fraction by 2, we can simply divide the numerator by 2. 4 ÷ 2 = 2, and the denominator stays the same, so we get 2/8.
explanations.C: When dividing a fraction by an integer, we do sometimes multiply the denominator by that integer, but we do not do it at the same time as dividing the numerator. 2/16 is effectively 4 times smaller, rather than 2 times smaller.
explanations.D: We do not divide the denominator when dividing by an integer. To visualise this, imagine a cake split into 8 pieces. 4 slices are left, and you share those between 2 people. How much of the cake does each person get?

explanations.A: We do not divide the denominator when dividing by an integer. To visualise this, imagine a cake split into 9 pieces. 6 slices are left, and you share those between 3 people. How much of the cake does each person get?
explanations.B: When dividing a fraction by an integer, we do sometimes multiply the denominator by that integer, but we do not do it at the same time as dividing the numerator. 2/18 is effectively 9 times smaller, rather than 3 times smaller.
explanations.C: When we divide a fraction by 3, we can simply divide the numerator by 3. 6 ÷ 3 = 2, and the denominator stays the same, so we get 2/9.
explanations.D: When we divide a fraction, we don't need to divide the numerator and the denominator. 2/3 is equivalent to 6/9, rather than one third of it.
